Title: Beauty and the Beast
Review: The greatest of all the Disney films, Beauty and the Beast captures fairytale magic and all that is enchanting, while still being thrilling and witty. It’s primary characters are complex and its animation—state-of-the-art at the time—is still beautiful and some of Disney’s finest. It also designates sufficient time to developing the love story of its leads, something uncharacteristic of children’s film.

Title: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs
Review: Snow White could claim this position purely for its animation, dazzling today just as much as it was in 1937. However, it also offers a glimpse into early children’s film and storytelling, displaying the darker possibilities and more nuanced stories that were created in a time forgotten.

Title: The Lion King
Review: It’s amazing to me that Disney took a chance on a semi-original story (something it had almost no experience in). With that chance, they arrived at a beautifully scored and animated film with interesting themes to explore. Moreover, the movie demonstrates some of the best camera movement up to that point in animated film. However, I don’t care for the occasional attempts to lift the mood; it was a good drama as it was. Scar, while despicable and eerie, is not threatening. All-in-all, the Lion King is a great movie with a couple strong scenes (the stampede and death of scar most notably), but it does not establish the mood and epic feel it desired.

Title: Bambi
Review: This is a great coming-of-age story with well-crafted characters.

Title: Sleeping Beauty
Review: Sleeping Beauty defines what it means to be a fairytale; everything in the film (especially the world-design) is built toward that purpose.

Title: The Little Mermaid
Review: Unlike most children’s movies, Disney’s first installment toward their “Renaissance” was a full film with real character development. There are certainly minor flaws, but they pale in the shadow of this giant of a movie.

Title: Frozen
Review: Though its beginning is too rushed for effectiveness, Frozen is a beautiful, epic fairytale with excellent music and sweet storytelling.

Title: Mulan
Review: Mulan offers a good soundtrack and animation, but excels in its humor and villain characterization. It does, however, try too hard at times for laughs.

Title: The Black Cauldron
Review: This forgotten gem glimmers on rare occasion with excellent artwork and darker themes. Check out Ebert’s review on this flick.

Title: The Many Adventures of Winnie the Pooh
Review: This Disney classic captures the magic of childhood nostalgia and innocence.

Title: Moana
Review: Beautifully animated with great music, Moana transcends its cliched story with humor and heart.

Title: Zootopia
Review: Again, Disney delivers an aesthetically brilliant film with more thematic depth than normal.

Title: Pocahontas
Review: It’s clear that the creative strength behind this movie was blown on its powerful soundtrack and artistic flair and not much else.

Title: Tangled
Review: Tangled has a lot of tangible goodness, including one notably creative scene, yet some of the gags and characters feel a little stock.

Title: Meet the Robinsons
Review: This movie moves too quickly but manages funny, engaging characters nonetheless.

Title: Fantasia
Review: Though handicapped by its storylessness, Fantasia is undeniably enchanting.

Title: Lady and the Tramp
Review: Though not much else, this movie offers strong character development.

Title: Atlantis: The Lost Empire
Review: Not only a grand and epic fantasy, Atlantis boasts likable and dynamic characters.

Title: Lilo & Stitch
Review: Lilo & Stitch crafts a nuanced family dynamic alongside above-average animation.

Title: Tarzan
Review: This movie has a lot going for it—artistic strength, good music, easy pacing—but it never transcends, never becoming a great movie.

Title: Robin Hood
Review: Sweet, folksy, and simple, this movie—like The Adventures of Winnie the Pooh—captures nostalgia and whimsy. However, it does suffer from a hurried story and sub-par animation.

Title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame
Review: I have mixed feelings on this movie. It is often very dark and, for that reason, very powerful. It also has many dazzling visuals, but the animation could have been so much more; it often seems hollow or lacking up-close. I guess there is nothing wrong with making the dark source material into a happy ending like all the other Disney films since they are children entertainment, but my big problem is the movie’s theme of physical appearance not mattering (much like the theme from Beauty and the Beast). This is arguably the main theme of the movie in the midst of other dark subjects, and this main theme is ruined. Quasimodo is made less repulsive with a young voice and repeated songs trivializing his deformity. To boot, at the end, he isn’t even hesitant about losing the girl to the knight in shining armor. Some other slight complaints are that it, like other Disney movies, tries to lighten the mood in inappropriate places, and that it (and I care even less about this) steals from previous Disney movies—e.g. plot, characters, scenes, etc.

Title: Aladdin
Review: This movie dropped a lot for me with a more recent viewing. While the Genie character is strong and the climax excellent, it has little in the way of propulsion.

Title: Big Hero 6
Review: Though it is beautifully animated with an exciting second half, its pacing is too quick and it feels like it's just hitting the beats.

Title: The Fox and the Hound
Review: It offers a meaningful story through a great ending, but as a Disney musical, it falls flat.

Title: Pinocchio
Review: This classic has fun songs, good animation (though not as good as its predecessor), and a certain depth, but its themes are too on the nose and its pacing uneven.

Title: The Rescuers Down Under
Review: Distractingly implausible and inconsistent, this movie still demonstrates solid effects and a menacing villain.

Title: The Emperor's New Groove
Review: Truly fun with an excellent moral shift, The Emperor’s New Groove is a good movie lowered only by its poor animation and inability to compete with better films.

Title: Fantasia 2000
Review: Enchanting like its forerunner, this movie is solid despite its poor use of CGI.

Title: Oliver & Company
Review: This Disney movie acts as our point of inflection for quality. It boasts the musical talent of Billy Joel with a few flashes of quality animation, yet it offers no closure and the graphics are overwhelmingly bad.

Title: 101 Dalmatians
Review: While the villain is cinematically interesting, the movie is anti-climatic.

Title: Bolt
Review: It can be funny, but for the most part, the movie feels pretty generic.

Title: Alice in Wonderland
Review: Psychologically interesting for its nonsensical elements—and at times even sweet—Alice in Wonderland is still strange and distant.

Title: Hercules
Review: While the movie is entertaining and genuinely funny, the chosen style of animation is distractingly distasteful and the plotting is far too fast.

Title: The Princess and the Frog
Review: The thematic exploration is one of Disney’s best, as is the style and villain of the film, but in the end, the movie is too contrived and not patient with its own development.

Title: The Jungle Book
Review: It can be really fun at times, but it too suffers from rushed storytelling and character you never grow to care for.

Title: Wreck-it Ralph
Review: The premise is funny and some of the jokes are witty, but Wreck-It-Ralph lacks anything extraordinary.

Title: Treasure Planet
Review: The animation is pretty and the villain surprisingly complex, but the CGI has badly dated the movie.

Title: Fun & Fancy Free
Review: These miniature stories are good for what they are.

Title: Winnie the Pooh
Review: It fails to capture the magic of its predecessor.

Title: Peter Pan
Review: The characters are eccentric and therefore fun, but the movie lacks heart (and likable protagonists).

Title: Cinderella
Review: It’s sweet but too hurried for any real attachment.

Title: Dinosaur
Review: It’s pretty but cliche.

Title: The Great Mouse Detective
Review: The premise is fun, but the movie doesn’t do enough to build upon that premise.

Title: The Adventures of Ichabod and Mr. Toad
Review: These are great stories with no character development.

Title: Make Mine Music
Review: This is little more than cute stories with fun music.

Title: The Aristocats
Review: Don’t tell Lauren, but this movie isn’t great. It has some fun parts, but you never really care about its characters.

Title: Melody Time
Review: It’s a little less cute and a little less fun than Make Mine Music.

Title: Chicken Little
Review: The movie has heart and some solid jokes, but it tries too hard and the animation is lacking.

Title: Home on the Range
Review: It has some surprisingly good cinematography and music, but the story is cliche and the main character uninteresting.

Title: Brother Bear
Review: The movie suffers from an abundance of cliches; moreover, it montage-d its most important scene.

Title: The Sword in the Stone
Review: Nothing ever happens.

Title: Dumbo
Review: While one of its scenes is exceptionally potent, the rest is strange and distancing.

Title: Saludos Amigos
Review: There’s little to endear it to a viewer.

Title: The Three Caballeros
Review: There’s little to endear it to a viewer.

Title: The Rescuers
Review: It’s too hurried and scattered.
